channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: ‘Paranoia Is the Mother-in-Law of Invention,’ Puppet Accused of Terror in Egypt Tells BBC
item.description: In an English-language interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation on Friday, the Egyptian puppet recently accused of acting as a terrorist mouthpiece protested her innocence.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Iran Says All Outstanding Issues Resolved Over Implementing Nuclear Accord
item.description: The Iranian assertion came at the end of a two-day meeting of deputy negotiators in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New Detail Emerges About Bo Xilai’s Downfall
item.description: A new article says John Garnaut, a prominent Australian reporter based in Beijing for the Sydney Morning Herald, was called in to act as the interpreter for Wang Lijun, the former Chongqing police chief who reported his suspicion that Bo Xilai’s wife had murdered the British businessman Neil Heywood.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Bo Guagua, left, with his father, Bo Xilai, in 2007.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 10
item.description: The International Kite Festival in Dhordo, Gujarat.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Central African Republic Leader Resigns
item.description: Michel Djotodia quit under pressure on Friday after regional leaders held him responsible for failing to halt continuing sectarian violence in the country.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: President Michel Djotodia of the Central African Republic, left, shook hands with assembled dignitaries as he departed for Chad on Wednesday.

item.title: Letter From Africa: Colonial Ghosts Continue to Haunt France
item.description: Paris finds itself stuck in a quagmire in Central African Republic that has been decades in the making.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Israel Publishes Plans for New Housing in Settlements
item.description: A chief Palestinian negotiator called the plan for 1,400 units in East Jerusalem and the West Bank a “slap” to a peace deal.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: The Lede: French Court Upholds Ban on Comedian Who Mocks Holocaust Commemoration
item.description: A French appeals court upheld a ban on performances by the stand-up comedian known as Dieudonné, who invented an obscene salute popular with anti-Semites.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: Mumbai’s International Airport Gets Modern Makeover
item.description: The addition of Terminal 2 is Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport’s first major upgrade in nearly 30 years.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: The corridor designed for arrivals at the integrated Terminal T2 of the Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: French President Threatens to Sue Over Report of Affair
item.description: President François Hollande condemned a glossy French tabloid, Closer, for publishing pictures it says show that he had late-night meetings with a French actress.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Coastal Province’s Fishing Rules Alarm U.S.
item.description: The United States reacted with dismay to new rules issued by Hainan Province in China that require foreign fishing vessels to obtain permission from the Chinese government before plying disputed sea waters that China claims.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Fishermen bustle with their wares in Hainan, where the provincial government says that foreign fishing vessels must obtain approval to enter waters it says are under its jurisdiction.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Online Game Offers Chance to Blast Corruption
item.description: “Beat Corruption,” which lets players zap greedy officials, was released amid a push to eradicate government corruption and curb a culture of extravagant gift-giving among officials.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A new online game allows users to win points by blasting greedy officials (and lose them by hitting virtuous police officers).

item.title: With Release of Prisoners, Afghan Leader Again Defies U.S. Wishes
item.description: Intensifying his showdown with Washington, President Hamid Karzai ordered the release of 72 detainees, citing insufficient evidence.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: The facility near Bagram, Afghanistan, where prisoners were being held. A State Department spokeswoman called those being released “dangerous criminals.”

item.title: Germany to Help in Disposal of Syrian Chemical Weapons
item.description: The decision was in part to maintain international credibility in addressing Syria’s civil war, the foreign minister said.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: A training grenade was dismantled during a demonstration at a chemical weapons disposal facility near Munster in October.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: The Wu-Force on Fusing the Sounds of China and the U.S.
item.description: Called a “kung fu-Appalachian avant folk-rock” band, the Wu-Force combine musical traditions from East and West, pairing a banjo with a Chinese zither.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN ANSFIELD

item.title: India Ink: Illiterate, but in Love With Books
item.description: Muhammad Latif Oata can’t read, but his passion for stories has led him to collect hundreds of books, which he has turned into a library at Dal Lake in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By MAJID MAQBOOL

item.title: Indian Diplomat Flies Home After Indictment in U.S.
item.description: Devyani Khobragade’s return to India represented a possible resolution of a case that has harmed U.S. ties with New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Falluja’s Fall Stuns Marines Who Fought There
item.description: The bloody mission to wrest Falluja from insurgents in November 2004 meant more to the Marines than almost any other battle in the 12 years of war in Iraq and Afghanistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marines fighting insurgents in Falluja in 2004. The insurgents are back, and many Marines wonder if their sacrifice was in vain.

item.title: Santiago Journal: A Chilean Dictator’s Secret Book Collection: Heavy on Napoleon, Light on Fiction
item.description: General Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, known for his brutal 17-year rule, amassed about 50,000 volumes for his private library, using public money.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roberto Mardones of the President Pinochet Foundation, which got some of the leader’s books.

item.title: U.S. Considers Resuming Nonlethal Aid to Syrian Opposition
item.description: Officials insisted that no nonlethal supplies would be given directly to Syria’s Islamist groups, but questions remained over how to keep it from ending up in the wrong hands.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Damaged buildings line a street in the besieged city of Homs. American officials say restoring aid to Syria would send a message of support ahead of Jan. 22 talks.

item.title: Syria Militants Said to Recruit Visiting Americans to Attack U.S.
item.description: American intelligence and counterterrorism officials said Islamic extremist groups were trying to identify, recruit and train Westerners to carry out attacks when they returned home.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Polio Vaccination Effort in Syria Appears to Have Some Effect
item.description: The outbreak of the disease appears to have been contained halfway through an emergency vaccination effort for millions of children in the Middle East.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Find Dead Tiger in S.U.V. in Wenzhou
item.description: The police report said the authorities suspected the carcass to be of a Siberian, or Amur, tiger, one of the world’s most endangered animals, and had sent samples to be tested.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: The police were surprised when they unwrapped the bound tarpaulin the men had been carrying.

item.title: After Being Indicted, Diplomat Is Allowed to Leave the Country
item.description: Devyani Khobragade, an Indian diplomat, was indicted on charges of visa fraud and making false statements in connection with her treatment of a domestic worker.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: The Consulate General of India on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where Ms. Khobragade had her office.

item.title: U.S. Mission in South Sudan Shows Limits of Military
item.description: Recent evacuation efforts highlight the remaining gaps in intelligence and communications that American forces face in Africa, commanders and independent analysts said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
